head.title: Tech 2010: #29 Wait No More; The Elevator You Never Have to Wait For

hedline.hl1: Tech 2010: #29 Wait No More; The Elevator You Never Have to Wait For

abstract.p: Otis Elevator Company is developing Odyssey system in which elevators can skip sideways from shaft to shaft, ending age of traveling dumbly up and down (S)

block.p: No more staring at closed elevator doors, repeatedly pressing a call button in frustration. No more standing at the rear of the car, willing the elevator to make it to your floor without another God-forsaken stop. No more traveling dumbly up and down, a modern-day Babbitt in a tin can in its dark and solitary shaft.

Otis Elevator Company plans to liberate the elevator -- and the elevator rider -- by letting them skip sideways from shaft to shaft. They imagine cars moving up and down buildings like roadsters on a freeway rather than buckets in a well.

No more staring at closed elevator doors, repeatedly pressing a call button in frustration. No more standing at the rear of the car, willing the elevator to make it to your floor without another God-forsaken stop. No more traveling dumbly up and down, a modern-day Babbitt in a tin can in its dark and solitary shaft.

Otis Elevator Company plans to liberate the elevator -- and the elevator rider -- by letting them skip sideways from shaft to shaft. They imagine cars moving up and down buildings like roadsters on a freeway rather than buckets in a well.

This makes several things possible. First, it allows multiple elevators to occupy a hoistway at any one time, which means that not only does the ratio of cars to riders in a building increase (think back to the dozen people crammed crankily into your elevator each morning) but also that the halting progress of the one-car-one-shaft system can be made obsolete. If you're traveling up to the 75th floor, for example, and above you there are cars stopping on 17, 28, 39 and 57, then the computer on your car, in constant communication with the others, will read the situation and adjust accordingly, sliding laterally into a neighboring shaft and keeping you on the move.
